sourceText: Hi! Every child has challenging behaviour sometimes. If you would like some tips, type 'Help'.
text: Hi! Every child has challenging behaviour sometimes. If you would like some tips, type 'Help'.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: Today's Tip is about how we can support our teens when they experience really difficult situations.
text: Today's Tip is about how we can support our teens when they experience really difficult situations.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: When our children share difficult experiences with us, we may initially get angry because we are afraid for them. But that is when we need to stay calm, listen, and be open.
text: When our children share difficult experiences with us, we may initially get angry because we are afraid for them. But that is when we need to stay calm, listen, and be open.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
text: Here are some things you can do when your teen shares something difficult with you:
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: 1. Take a deep breath before you respond.
text: 1. Take a deep breath before you respond.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: 2. Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
text: 2. Listen to what your child is saying. Notice how they are feeling.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: 3. Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"
text: 3. Notice how you feel. Ask yourself, "What does my child need right now?"
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: 4. Reassure your child that you are there for them.
text: 4. Reassure your child that you are there for them.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: 5. You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
text: 5. You can deal with the consequences later but right now your child needs you.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: 6. Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.
text: 6. Discuss possible solutions or next steps to take action.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: 7. Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.
text: 7. Remind your child again that you love them and thank them for sharing with you.
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! We understand that this can be really difficult. Supporting your child through a crisis will also teach them how to support others in difficult times. Good for you!
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! We understand that this can be really difficult. Supporting your child through a crisis will also teach them how to support others in difficult times. Good for you!
note: This is for topic Crisis Support

sourceText: Today's Tip is about how we can help to protect our children.
text: Today's Tip is about how we can help to protect our children.
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things that can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.
text: The idea of talking to children about abuse can be scary. We don't know what to say. But there are some simple things that can help them understand when it is not OK to be touched, and that they can tell you if something ever happens.
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:
text: Here are 3 things that you should make sure your child knows to protect them from abuse:
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: 1. Learn about private parts
text: 1. Learn about private parts
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.
text: The parts of their body that go under people's underwear or a swimsuit are private parts. It is not OK for other people to touch or to ask to look at them, or ask them to look at or touch theirs.
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: 2. Your body belongs to you
text: 2. Your body belongs to you
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.
text: If someone tries to touch your children's private parts they must say NO and tell a grown up that they trust.
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: 3. Bad secrets should be told.
text: 3. Bad secrets should be told.
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.
text: Your children should tell you if there is a secret that makes them feel worried. You will not be angry. Only nice secrets - like a surprise birthday party - should be kept secret.
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: We understand that this can be really difficult. Please type "Help" if you want any extra support or guidance.
text: We understand that this can be really difficult. Please type "Help" if you want any extra support or guidance.
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Supporting your child through a crisis will also teach them how to support others in difficult times. Good for you!
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Supporting your child through a crisis will also teach them how to support others in difficult times. Good for you!
note: This is for topic GoodBad Touch

sourceText: Today's tip is about how we can support positive family relationships at home.
text: Today's tip is about how we can support positive family relationships at home.
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Here are 6 simple steps for more family harmony at home:
text: Here are 6 simple steps for more family harmony at home:
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: 1. Be a model of behaviour for your children
text: 1. Be a model of behaviour for your children
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.
text: How we talk and behave in front of our children is a big influence on how they behave too! The more we practice modeling peaceful, loving relationships for our children, the more secure and loved they will feel.
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: 2. Use positive language. It works!
text: 2. Use positive language. It works!
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
text: Tell others what you want them to do instead of what you don’t want them to do: Instead of “Stop shouting,” try “Please speak more quietly”
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Praise others to make them feel appreciated. Saying “Thank you for clearing the dinner” can make a big difference.
text: Praise others to make them feel appreciated. Saying “Thank you for clearing the dinner” can make a big difference.
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: 3. Be a great listener
text: 3. Be a great listener
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”
text: Listen to others when they are talking with you. Be open and show them that you hear what they are saying. It can help to summarise what you have heard before responding: “What I hear you saying is…”
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: 4. Share the load
text: 4. Share the load
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
text: Looking after children and other family members is difficult, but it’s much easier when responsibilities are shared. Try to share household chores, childcare, and other tasks equally amongst family members
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: 5. Take care of yourself
text: 5. Take care of yourself
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed.
text: Create a schedule for time “on” and time “off” with other adults in your household. It is okay to ask for help when you are feeling tired or stressed.
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: When you see arguments building up, agree to take a break and go into another room or outside if you can.
text: When you see arguments building up, agree to take a break and go into another room or outside if you can.
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: 6. Do nice things together as a family
text: 6. Do nice things together as a family
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!
text: Let each family member take turns choosing a whole family activity. Find ways to spend time alone with other adults in your home, too!
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit!  Every time you resolve conflicts in a peaceful way, you increase your child's brain development. Be proud of yourself when you do it!
text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit!  Every time you resolve conflicts in a peaceful way, you increase your child's brain development. Be proud of yourself when you do it!
note: This is for topic Family Harmony

sourceText: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet, which can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. When you make a family budget, you agree on how to spend and save money together. This can help you have enough at the end of the month (so you need to borrow less) and help children understand that we all need to make hard decisions.
text: Millions of families are struggling to make ends meet, which can make us feel anxious, stressed, and sad. When you make a family budget, you agree on how to spend and save money together. This can help you have enough at the end of the month (so you need to borrow less) and help children understand that we all need to make hard decisions.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: Here are 4 quick steps to make a budget and save money together as a family:
text: Here are 4 quick steps to make a budget and save money together as a family:
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: 1. What do we spend on now?
text: 1. What do we spend on now?
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • Get a piece of paper or cardboard and a pen.
text: • Get a piece of paper or cardboard and a pen.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
text: • Draw pictures of all the things that you and your family spend money on each month.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
text: • Write next to each picture how much each thing costs.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • Add up how much money you have to spend each month.
text: • Add up how much money you have to spend each month.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: 2. Talk about needs and wants
text: 2. Talk about needs and wants
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • Needs: Which things are important or must haves for your family to survive? (like food, soap to wash hands, needs for ill or disabled family members).
text: • Needs: Which things are important or must haves for your family to survive? (like food, soap to wash hands, needs for ill or disabled family members).
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • Wants: Which things are nice to have but not essential?
text: • Wants: Which things are nice to have but not essential?
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: Discuss with your children where you can spend less as a family.
text: Discuss with your children where you can spend less as a family.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: 3. Build your own budget
text: 3. Build your own budget
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • Find some stones or small objects. This is your money for the month.
text: • Find some stones or small objects. This is your money for the month.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • As a family, decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones on your picture.
text: • As a family, decide what you will spend on what, and put the stones on your picture.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: • If you can save even a tiny amount for the future or an emergency  – it can make a big difference over time.
text: • If you can save even a tiny amount for the future or an emergency  – it can make a big difference over time.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: 4. Find out where you can get extra help
text: 4. Find out where you can get extra help
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: Your government or community groups may be giving money, or food parcels to families during COVID-19.
text: Your government or community groups may be giving money, or food parcels to families during COVID-19.
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Learning ways to manage money as a family has reduced arguments and stress for millions of families. That's real success!
text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Learning ways to manage money as a family has reduced arguments and stress for millions of families. That's real success!
note: This is for topic Family Budgeting

sourceText: Hello! This is a stressful time, especially for parents. When we are stressed or angry, we do not make the best decisions. Taking the time to care for ourselves will help us care for our children.
text: Hello! This is a stressful time, especially for parents. When we are stressed or angry, we do not make the best decisions. Taking the time to care for ourselves will help us care for our children.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Today's tip is about how to keep calm and manage stress in our busy lives.
text: Today's tip is about how to keep calm and manage stress in our busy lives.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Taking a Pause is a simple relaxation activity that you can do whenever you are feeling stressed or worried. It can also be helpful when you find your child is irritating you or has done something wrong.
text: Taking a Pause is a simple relaxation activity that you can do whenever you are feeling stressed or worried. It can also be helpful when you find your child is irritating you or has done something wrong.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Step 1. Close your eyes and take a deep breath.
text: Step 1. Close your eyes and take a deep breath.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Step 2. Ask yourself, "What am I thinking?" Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative.
text: Step 2. Ask yourself, "What am I thinking?" Notice if your thoughts are positive or negative.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Notice how you are feeling emotionally. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Remind yourself that whatever you feel, it is okay.
text: Notice how you are feeling emotionally. Notice if your emotions are pleasant or unpleasant. Remind yourself that whatever you feel, it is okay.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.
text: Notice how your body feels. Notice anything that hurts or is tense.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Step 3. Focus on your breath. Feel your breath as it goes in and out. You can put a hand on your stomach and feel it rise and fall with each breath. Do this for about 10 breaths.
text: Step 3. Focus on your breath. Feel your breath as it goes in and out. You can put a hand on your stomach and feel it rise and fall with each breath. Do this for about 10 breaths.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Step 4. Expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room.
text: Step 4. Expand your awareness to your whole body. Listen to the sounds in the room.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Step 5. Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different. When you are ready, open your eyes.
text: Step 5. Take a moment to reflect on whether you feel any different. When you are ready, open your eyes.
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Well done for Taking a Pause. You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit!
text: Well done for Taking a Pause. You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit!
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: You can do this anytime you are feeling stressed. It gives you a chance to be calmer. Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also Take a Pause with your Children!
text: You can do this anytime you are feeling stressed. It gives you a chance to be calmer. Even a few deep breaths or connecting with the ground beneath you can make a difference. You can also Take a Pause with your Children!
topicTitle: Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause
note: This is for topic Keep Calm and Manage Stress including Take a Pause

sourceText: Hi! How are you feeling right now? Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful.
text: Hi! How are you feeling right now? Have you only got 30 seconds? Let's take a quick pause together. It might be helpful.
note: This is for topic Short Pause

sourceText: Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready, open your eyes again. Everything is okay.
text: Sit down, close your eyes and listen to your breath as it goes in and out. Notice how you feel. When you are ready, open your eyes again. Everything is okay.
note: This is for topic Short Pause

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
note: This is for topic Short Pause

sourceText: Hello! How are you feeling? If you are feeling overwhelmed or stressed, here is a short activity that can help when you are feeling like needing some more support to get through the day.
text: Hello! How are you feeling? If you are feeling overwhelmed or stressed, here is a short activity that can help when you are feeling like needing some more support to get through the day.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: Recognise what is happening for you in this moment. What are you thinking? Are your thoughts positive or negative. How do you feel? Do you feel pleasant or unpleasant? How does your body feel? Do you feel tense or relaxed?
text: Recognise what is happening for you in this moment. What are you thinking? Are your thoughts positive or negative. How do you feel? Do you feel pleasant or unpleasant? How does your body feel? Do you feel tense or relaxed?
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: Sit comfortably and close your eyes. Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. You can then say the following words silently to yourself:
text: Sit comfortably and close your eyes. Connect to your heart in a kind and gentle way. You may want to place one hand on your heart or chest. You can then say the following words silently to yourself:
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: May I be peaceful.
text: May I be peaceful.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: May I be safe.
text: May I be safe.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: May I be healthy.
text: May I be healthy.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: May I be happy.
text: May I be happy.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: May there be love in my family.
text: May there be love in my family.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: May I feel loved.
text: May I feel loved.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: Before you open your eyes, take a moment to reflect on your experience. Notice if you feel any different.
text: Before you open your eyes, take a moment to reflect on your experience. Notice if you feel any different.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
note: This is for topic Loving Kindness

sourceText: Hello! Did you know that 3 is a magical number? Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?
text: Hello! Did you know that 3 is a magical number? Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different?
note: This is for topic Magical Number

sourceText: What are your three favourite foods? Can you name three things you can see right now? Can you hear three sounds you can hear right now? What are three things you are grateful for right now?
text: What are your three favourite foods? Can you name three things you can see right now? Can you hear three sounds you can hear right now? What are three things you are grateful for right now?
note: This is for topic Magical Number

sourceText: Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Three is a magical number!
text: Breathe in to the count of three and breathe out to the count of three. How do you feel now? Do you feel any different? Three is a magical number!
note: This is for topic Magical Number

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
note: This is for topic Magical Number

sourceText: Hello! We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving, money, and COVID-19 can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.
text: Hello! We love our children and teenagers, but stress from caregiving, money, and COVID-19 can make us angry. Here is how we can maintain control and keep calm.
note: This is for topic When we are angry

sourceText: Stop the river at the source. The same things usually make us get stressed and angry every time. What makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?
text: Stop the river at the source. The same things usually make us get stressed and angry every time. What makes you angry? When does it happen? How do you normally react?
note: This is for topic When we are angry

sourceText: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.
text: Prevent anger from starting in the first place. Get some sleep or rest when you are tired. Try to eat something when you are hungry. Ask someone for support when you are feeling alone.
note: This is for topic When we are angry

sourceText: Here are some things that can help make it less likely that bad things happen when you are angry:
text: Here are some things that can help make it less likely that bad things happen when you are angry:
note: This is for topic When we are angry

sourceText: 1. Cut back on drinking alcohol or don’t drink, especially when the kids are awake.
text: 1. Cut back on drinking alcohol or don’t drink, especially when the kids are awake.
note: This is for topic When we are angry

sourceText: 2. Do you have weapons or things  that can be used to hurt others?  Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.
text: 2. Do you have weapons or things  that can be used to hurt others?  Lock them up, hide them or take them out of the home.
note: This is for topic When we are angry

sourceText: 3. It’s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.
text: 3. It’s ok to have your children stay somewhere safe or take them to a place where they can get help.
note: This is for topic When we are angry

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Learning how to manage your anger can help you  avoid some difficult situations.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit. Learning how to manage your anger can help you  avoid some difficult situations.
note: This is for topic When we are angry

sourceText: Hi! Managing anger can be really difficult. Take a break when you feel you are getting angry at your children or someone else.
text: Hi! Managing anger can be really difficult. Take a break when you feel you are getting angry at your children or someone else.
note: This is for topic Anger Management

sourceText: Go somewhere else for 5 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside. You can get through this!
text: Go somewhere else for 5 minutes to regain control of your emotions. If you have safe outdoor space, go outside. You can get through this!
note: This is for topic Anger Management

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
note: This is for topic Anger Management

sourceText: Hello! Here's a fun physical activity that can help release stress and keep healthy.
text: Hello! Here's a fun physical activity that can help release stress and keep healthy.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.
text: Stand up and stretch your arms up to the sky. Push away any clouds and let the sun shine down on you. Stretch to both sides. Stretch to the front and to the back.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Let your hand hang by your side. Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you relax your body.
text: Let your hand hang by your side. Squeeze your shoulders tightly up to your ears as you breathe in, scrunch your eyes, and hold your breath. Release your shoulders as you relax your body.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Relax your arms and let your arms swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
text: Relax your arms and let your arms swing sideways, and turn your upper body. Your arms should gently hit your back as you twist from side to side.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
text: Place one foot in front of the other and make small circles from ankles, remember to turn to both sides. Do each foot with four circles in each direction.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!
text: Now shake your whole body as fast as you can. Shake it up high! Shake it down low! Shake it all around!
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out.
text: Close your eyes and raise your arms slowly above your head as you breathe in. Lower your arms slowly to your side as you breathe out.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Take a moment to reflect on your experience.
text: Take a moment to reflect on your experience.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: Physical exercise is a great way to reduce stress and keep healthy. You can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.
text: Physical exercise is a great way to reduce stress and keep healthy. You can do this activity at any time whenever you feel like you need to release stress and energise your mind and body.
note: This is for topic Exercise

sourceText: We are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps reduce the impact of COVID-19 and encourages us to continue with our lives…but it also presents risks and dangers.
text: We are now spending a lot more time online. Being connected helps reduce the impact of COVID-19 and encourages us to continue with our lives…but it also presents risks and dangers.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: Here are 5 tips that can help you keep yourself safe online:
text: Here are 5 tips that can help you keep yourself safe online:
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: 1. Learn about risks and dangers
text: 1. Learn about risks and dangers
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: • Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
text: • Adults targeting people for sexual purposes on social media, gaming, and messaging platforms.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: • Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
text: • Harmful content – like violence, hating women, hating foreigners, encouraging suicide and self-harm, misinformation, pornography
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: • Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.
text: • Sharing personal information and sexual photos or videos.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: • Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.
text: • Cyberbullying from other people and strangers.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: 2. Here are some quick tech fixes to reduce risks:
text: 2. Here are some quick tech fixes to reduce risks:
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: • Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
text: • Turn on SafeSearch on your browser to filter adult content.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: • Set up parental controls.
text: • Set up parental controls.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: • Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
text: • Set up strict privacy settings on online apps and games.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: • Cover webcams when not in use.
text: • Cover webcams when not in use.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:
text: 3. Create healthy and safe online habits:
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).
text: You can also create healthy and safe online habits like creating device-free spaces and times in your house (eating, playing, schoolwork, and sleeping).
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: 4. Maintain privacy
text: 4. Maintain privacy
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are! Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
text: Keep personal information private, especially from strangers. – some people are not who they say they are! Remember that what goes online stays online (messages, photos, and videos).
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: 5. Report and seek help
text: 5. Report and seek help
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals to get support if you experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.
text: Report to INHOPE Hotlines and IWF portals to get support if you experience online violence or other things that are not acceptable.
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Digital parenting is just like parenting in the real world. You have taken a BIG STEP to keeping you and your children safe online. Good for you!
text: Well done! You have added another skill to your Parenting Toolkit! Digital parenting is just like parenting in the real world. You have taken a BIG STEP to keeping you and your children safe online. Good for you!
note: This is for topic Online Safety

sourceText: When your children ask you about COVID-19, be willing to talk. They will already have heard something. Silence and secrets do not protect our children. Honesty and openness do. Think about how much they will understand. You know them best.
text: When your children ask you about COVID-19, be willing to talk. They will already have heard something. Silence and secrets do not protect our children. Honesty and openness do. Think about how much they will understand. You know them best.
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Here are 4 simple steps that you can do when talking about COVID-19 with your children:
text: Here are 4 simple steps that you can do when talking about COVID-19 with your children:
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Step 1. Be open, honest, and supportive
text: Step 1. Be open, honest, and supportive
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Allow your child to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.
text: Allow your child to talk freely. Ask them open questions and find out how much they already know.
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old your child is and how much they can understand.
text: Always answer their questions truthfully. Think about how old your child is and how much they can understand.
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Your child may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.
text: Your child may be scared or confused. Give them space to share how they are feeling and let them know you are there for them.
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Step 2. It is OK not to know the answers.
text: Step 2. It is OK not to know the answers.
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with your child. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn
text: It is fine to say “We don’t know, but we are working on it; or we don’t know, ‘but we think’.”  Use this as an opportunity to learn something new with your child. The WHO and UNICEF websites are great first steps to learn
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Step 3. Be a hero not a bully
text: Step 3. Be a hero not a bully
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Explain that COVID-19 has nothing to do with the way someone looks, where they are from, or what language they speak.
text: Explain that COVID-19 has nothing to do with the way someone looks, where they are from, or what language they speak.
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Tell your child that we can be compassionate to people who are sick and those who are caring for them.
text: Tell your child that we can be compassionate to people who are sick and those who are caring for them.
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Step 4. End on a good note
text: Step 4. End on a good note
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Check to see if your child is okay. Remind them that you care and that they can talk to you anytime. Then do something fun together!
text: Check to see if your child is okay. Remind them that you care and that they can talk to you anytime. Then do something fun together!
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! When you talk about COVID-19 with your child in a supportive way, you make them feel loved and safe. You are the hero of this story!
text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! When you talk about COVID-19 with your child in a supportive way, you make them feel loved and safe. You are the hero of this story!
note: This is for topic Talking about COVID-19

sourceText: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.
text: All children, including those living with disabilities, need love, respect and time especially at difficult times.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities:
text: Here are 6 simple tips that you can do to support children living with disabilities:
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: 1. Keep your child safe and well
text: 1. Keep your child safe and well
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
text: • Keep your country's COVID-19 rules, and help your child to be active - do whatever exercise you can with them inside or outside your home
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see
text: • Keep emergency contact numbers somewhere easy to see
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: 2. Try to understand how they are feeling
text: 2. Try to understand how they are feeling
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Your child may be feeling stressed, anxious, and frustrated.
text: • Your child may be feeling stressed, anxious, and frustrated.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Tell them you love them
text: • Tell them you love them
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: 3. Talk and communicate with your child
text: 3. Talk and communicate with your child
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Get down to your child’s level when you speak.
text: • Get down to your child’s level when you speak.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Look at them and smile
text: • Look at them and smile
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Give them time to tell you or show you what they think
text: • Give them time to tell you or show you what they think
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Tell your child that you understand
text: • Tell your child that you understand
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: 4. Praise them!
text: 4. Praise them!
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Praise them for behaving well, and for trying.
text: • Praise them for behaving well, and for trying.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.
text: • Focus on what they can do, not what they can't.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Only help children when they need it. This helps to build independence!
text: • Only help children when they need it. This helps to build independence!
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: 5. Make a daily plan
text: 5. Make a daily plan
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.
text: • Having things that are the same each day helps children feel secure and safe.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Include some things they like to do.
text: • Include some things they like to do.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
text: • Give your child choices: this gives them a sense of control and builds self-esteem.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Use simple language and clear instructions. If words don’t work, try gestures and pictures.
text: • Use simple language and clear instructions. If words don’t work, try gestures and pictures.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: 6. Ask for help
text: 6. Ask for help
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Share the load with other adult family members.
text: • Share the load with other adult family members.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: •  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.
text: •  You are not alone! Keep connected with people who understand your situation.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Share your challenges AND your successes.
text: • Share your challenges AND your successes.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.
text: • It is normal to feel stressed, frustrated, and afraid at this time.
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: • Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!
text: • Be kind to yourself and take a break when you need to!
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Children with disabilities need love, respect and time – just like any other child
text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Children with disabilities need love, respect and time – just like any other child
note: This is for topic Children with Disabilities

sourceText: Sometimes we feel frustrated with our children because we expect them to behave in ways that they are not yet developmentally ready for.
text: Sometimes we feel frustrated with our children because we expect them to behave in ways that they are not yet developmentally ready for.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Introduction

sourceText: Learning about child development means we can have realistic expectations and spot any problems with their growth and development.
text: Learning about child development means we can have realistic expectations and spot any problems with their growth and development.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Introduction

sourceText: All children develop at different rates. But there are some things that we expect children to be able to do at an age. These are called ‘development’ milestones.
text: All children develop at different rates. But there are some things that we expect children to be able to do at an age. These are called ‘development’ milestones.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Introduction

sourceText: Many things affect our children's development. Development is helped by eating healthy food, having immunisations, and parents or caregivers who talk to children a lot.
text: Many things affect our children's development. Development is helped by eating healthy food, having immunisations, and parents or caregivers who talk to children a lot.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Introduction

sourceText: Babies from 0 to 1 year need a strong bond with a parent or caregiver who provides food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety. They need lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!
text: Babies from 0 to 1 year need a strong bond with a parent or caregiver who provides food, sleep, cleaning, comfort and safety. They need lots of play and attention - the most active time of brain development is during the first 1000 days of life!
note: This is for topic Child Development - Babies & toddlers (0 - 2 years)

sourceText: * From 0 to 6 months, babies smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.
text: * From 0 to 6 months, babies smile, babble and cry to attract your attention. We should provide care, cuddling and protection.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Babies & toddlers (0 - 2 years)

sourceText: * From 6 to 11 months, babies cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened.
text: * From 6 to 11 months, babies cling to you, especially when feeling insecure or frightened.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Babies & toddlers (0 - 2 years)

sourceText: * From 12 months onwards, most babies start to walk, talk and explore things around them!
text: * From 12 months onwards, most babies start to walk, talk and explore things around them!
note: This is for topic Child Development - Babies & toddlers (0 - 2 years)

sourceText: Toddlers from 1 to 2 years become curious little explorers - watch out for climbing! They learn through play and trying things out. They want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions. Praise them frequently to encourage them!
text: Toddlers from 1 to 2 years become curious little explorers - watch out for climbing! They learn through play and trying things out. They want to learn how to do new things (like getting dressed) and make their own decisions. Praise them frequently to encourage them!
note: This is for topic Child Development - Babies & toddlers (0 - 2 years)

sourceText: Toddlers start learning new words and speaking in sentences. They do not like to lose, share or take turns, so use opportunities to start teaching them how to handle these situations calmly. They may express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!), but with your patient help, they can start to learn how to manage their feelings.
text: Toddlers start learning new words and speaking in sentences. They do not like to lose, share or take turns, so use opportunities to start teaching them how to handle these situations calmly. They may express feelings in dramatic ways (like screaming on the floor!), but with your patient help, they can start to learn how to manage their feelings.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Babies & toddlers (0 - 2 years)

sourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Knowing about child development can help you feel less frustrated by your children’s behaviour.
text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Knowing about child development can help you feel less frustrated by your children’s behaviour.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Babies & toddlers (0 - 2 years)

sourceText: Young children from 2 to 5 years still have many of the same needs as toddlers. They learn through actions and play, and start developing friendships with other children. Young children often find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. They may talk a lot and ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more.
text: Young children from 2 to 5 years still have many of the same needs as toddlers. They learn through actions and play, and start developing friendships with other children. Young children often find it difficult to separate make-believe from reality. They may talk a lot and ask many questions. We should be honest when we reply! Our child may ask again if they don't understand or want to know more.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Children (2 - 9 years)

sourceText: Young children usually continue to express their feelings in dramatic ways, especially if they have to do something they don’t like! Keep teaching them patiently how to manage their emotions and responses if they lose, have to share, or need to take turns.
text: Young children usually continue to express their feelings in dramatic ways, especially if they have to do something they don’t like! Keep teaching them patiently how to manage their emotions and responses if they lose, have to share, or need to take turns.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Children (2 - 9 years)

sourceText: Older children of 6 to 9 years get more interested in learning at school and spending time with other children – they can be very active! Children may answer back to adults to show that they “know”. It is important to build your child’s independence and trust them to do simple and safe tasks without your assistance.
text: Older children of 6 to 9 years get more interested in learning at school and spending time with other children – they can be very active! Children may answer back to adults to show that they “know”. It is important to build your child’s independence and trust them to do simple and safe tasks without your assistance.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Children (2 - 9 years)

sourceText: At this age, children can be very self-conscious and sensitive, so recognise and speak with them about their emotions and about questions they may have around topics like religion. By now, they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.
text: At this age, children can be very self-conscious and sensitive, so recognise and speak with them about their emotions and about questions they may have around topics like religion. By now, they should be getting better at managing anger and frustration.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Children (2 - 9 years)

sourceText: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Knowing about child development can help you feel less frustrated by your children’s behaviour.
text: Well done for adding another tool to your Parenting Toolkit! Knowing about child development can help you feel less frustrated by your children’s behaviour.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Children (2 - 9 years)

sourceText: The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!
text: The teen years are the second most active time of brain development!
note: This is for topic Child Development - Teenagers (10 - 17 years)

sourceText: Young teenagers of 10 to 12 years continue to gain interest in learning at school and spending time with other teens. Their interest in religion or spirituality may grow.
text: Young teenagers of 10 to 12 years continue to gain interest in learning at school and spending time with other teens. Their interest in religion or spirituality may grow.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Teenagers (10 - 17 years)

sourceText: Young teenagers may answer back to you more frequently to show you they know “how”. They can feel very self-conscious and sensitive, so trust them to do more tasks independently to build their self-esteem. Continue to spend time with them, so you know what is going on in their lives and can help them manage difficult emotions like anger and frustration.
text: Young teenagers may answer back to you more frequently to show you they know “how”. They can feel very self-conscious and sensitive, so trust them to do more tasks independently to build their self-esteem. Continue to spend time with them, so you know what is going on in their lives and can help them manage difficult emotions like anger and frustration.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Teenagers (10 - 17 years)

sourceText: Teenagers of 13 to 14 years can often feel insecure and confused. They need a lot of affection, reassurance, and encouragement to help them believe in their abilities. Their feelings get hurt easily, and they may have mood swings, act bossy, and be unhappy when they lose.
text: Teenagers of 13 to 14 years can often feel insecure and confused. They need a lot of affection, reassurance, and encouragement to help them believe in their abilities. Their feelings get hurt easily, and they may have mood swings, act bossy, and be unhappy when they lose.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Teenagers (10 - 17 years)

sourceText: Their friends are increasingly important - also in their decision-making. They often begin to challenge rules that adults set for them at home or school. Make sure to give them some freedom, but also provide reliable rules that don’t change.
text: Their friends are increasingly important - also in their decision-making. They often begin to challenge rules that adults set for them at home or school. Make sure to give them some freedom, but also provide reliable rules that don’t change.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Teenagers (10 - 17 years)

sourceText: Teenagers of 15 to 17 years are able to communicate with you about almost anything – though they may prefer being with peers more than with you. They can have exciting new ideas and ideals, as they form their own identity. Encourage them to begin to take responsibility for the future. Be patient and accepting of the person they are becoming - even if it is not what you had imagined!
text: Teenagers of 15 to 17 years are able to communicate with you about almost anything – though they may prefer being with peers more than with you. They can have exciting new ideas and ideals, as they form their own identity. Encourage them to begin to take responsibility for the future. Be patient and accepting of the person they are becoming - even if it is not what you had imagined!
note: This is for topic Child Development - Teenagers (10 - 17 years)

sourceText: Teenagers have a growing sense of their sexuality, so they need guidance to make safe and healthy choices. They may show risk-taking behaviours, frequent mood swings, and rebellious attitudes. Monitor who their friends are and have clear rules to keep them safe. Keep supporting them, loving them, and guiding them so they feel comfortable and secure.
text: Teenagers have a growing sense of their sexuality, so they need guidance to make safe and healthy choices. They may show risk-taking behaviours, frequent mood swings, and rebellious attitudes. Monitor who their friends are and have clear rules to keep them safe. Keep supporting them, loving them, and guiding them so they feel comfortable and secure.
note: This is for topic Child Development - Teenagers (10 - 17 years)
